metadata.subject: Physical Sciences
metadata.contentDescriptor: Apply Newton's laws of motion to qualitatively describe, explain and predict the effects of forces on objects

A.levelDescription: Simplified concepts with visual support for students working 2-3 years below year level
whatYouWillLearn: How to describe the way things move
What makes things start moving, stop, or change direction
Why heavy things are harder to push than light things
How forces come in pairs
How these ideas explain everyday actions like sports and driving

sections.title: What is Motion?
sections.content: Motion is when something changes its position - it moves from one place to another. We describe motion using words like fast, slow, forward, backward, up, and down. Speed tells us how fast something is moving. If you walk 1 kilometre in 10 minutes, that's your speed. When we also include the direction of movement, scientists call this velocity. A car driving north at 60 km/h has a different velocity than one driving south at 60 km/h, even though their speeds are the same.
sections.visualDescription: Simple illustrations showing objects moving in different directions with arrows indicating their motion

sections.title: What are Forces?
sections.content: A force is a push or a pull. Forces can make things start moving, stop moving, speed up, slow down, or change direction. You use forces all the time - when you kick a ball, open a door, or pick up a book. Some forces need contact, like pushing a shopping trolley. Other forces can act without touching, like gravity pulling you toward Earth or a magnet attracting metal. Forces are measured in units called newtons (N), named after the scientist Isaac Newton.
sections.visualDescription: Pictures showing common forces: pushing, pulling, gravity, magnets

sections.title: Newton's First Law: Things Keep Doing What They're Doing
sections.content: Isaac Newton was a famous scientist who figured out the rules of motion about 350 years ago. His first law says that objects keep doing what they're doing unless a force makes them change. If something is sitting still, it will stay still unless you push it. If something is moving, it will keep moving in a straight line at the same speed until something stops it. This tendency to keep doing the same thing is called inertia. It's why you lurch forward when a car suddenly stops - your body wants to keep moving even though the car has stopped.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing a person lurching forward when a bus stops suddenly

sections.title: Newton's Second Law: Force Equals Mass Times Acceleration
sections.content: Newton's second law explains what happens when a force acts on an object. The heavier something is (more mass), the harder it is to change its motion. That's why it's easy to throw a tennis ball but hard to throw a bowling ball. When you apply a force, the object accelerates - it speeds up, slows down, or changes direction. A bigger force causes more acceleration. A heavier object needs more force to get the same acceleration as a lighter one. Scientists write this as F = ma, where F is force, m is mass, and a is acceleration.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison showing the same push applied to a shopping cart and a car, with different results

sections.title: Newton's Third Law: Every Action Has a Reaction
sections.content: Newton's third law says that forces always come in pairs. When you push on something, it pushes back on you with the same amount of force in the opposite direction. When you jump, you push down on the ground, and the ground pushes back up on you - that's what makes you go up! When a rocket launches, hot gases push out the bottom, and the rocket is pushed up. Action and reaction are always equal and opposite, but they act on different objects. That's why a skateboard moves backward when you step off it forward.
sections.visualDescription: Images showing action-reaction pairs: jumping, rowing a boat, rocket launch

sections.title: Weight and Mass
sections.content: Mass and weight are different things, even though we often use the words as if they're the same. Mass is how much matter is in an object - it's measured in kilograms and stays the same wherever you go. Weight is the force of gravity pulling on that mass - it's measured in newtons. On the Moon, you would weigh about one-sixth of what you weigh on Earth because the Moon's gravity is weaker. But your mass would be exactly the same. Astronauts in space feel weightless, but they still have the same mass.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison showing a person's mass and weight on Earth versus on the Moon

sections.title: Friction and Air Resistance
sections.content: Friction is a force that acts when surfaces rub together. It usually slows things down - that's why a ball eventually stops rolling. Friction can be helpful, like when your shoes grip the ground so you don't slip. It can also be unhelpful, like when bike parts wear out. Air resistance (also called drag) is a type of friction between moving objects and air. It slows down cars, planes, and falling objects. Parachutes use air resistance to slow skydivers. Streamlined shapes reduce air resistance, which is why sports cars and jets have smooth, curved designs.
sections.visualDescription: Diagrams showing friction between a shoe and ground, and air resistance on a parachute

sections.title: Forces in Sport
sections.content: Understanding forces helps athletes perform better. A tennis player uses force from their arm and racket to accelerate the ball. A swimmer pushes water backward, and the water pushes them forward (Newton's third law). Cyclists crouch low to reduce air resistance. AFL players know that heavier players are harder to stop (more inertia). Runners wear spikes to increase friction with the track. In sports science, researchers measure forces to help athletes train more effectively and design better equipment. Understanding Newton's laws is the key to understanding all sports.
sections.visualDescription: Sports examples showing forces in action: swimming, running, hitting a ball

caseStudy.title: Car Safety and Newton's Laws
caseStudy.content: Every year in Australia, road safety researchers use Newton's laws to design safer cars. In a crash, your body keeps moving (first law - inertia) even when the car suddenly stops. Without a seatbelt, you would slam into the steering wheel or windscreen at whatever speed the car was travelling. Seatbelts spread the stopping force across your body and give you more time to slow down. Airbags do the same thing - they slow you down more gently by spreading the force over more area and time. Crumple zones at the front and back of cars are designed to crush during a crash. This seems bad, but actually makes the crash safer because the crumpling takes time, reducing the force on passengers. ANCAP (Australasian New Car Assessment Program) crash tests cars to measure how well they protect people. They use dummies with sensors to measure the forces during a crash. Cars that protect passengers better get more safety stars. Understanding Newton's laws literally saves lives on Australian roads.
questions: How does a seatbelt protect you using Newton's first law?
Why do crumple zones make cars safer, not weaker?
How do airbags reduce the force on a person during a crash?

remember.question: What is Newton's first law of motion?
remember.sampleAnswer: Newton's first law states that an object will remain at rest or continue moving in a straight line at constant speed unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

understand.question: Explain why it's harder to push a shopping trolley full of groceries than an empty one.
understand.sampleAnswer: The full trolley has more mass than the empty one. According to Newton's second law (F = ma), more mass means you need more force to get the same acceleration. So to make the full trolley speed up at the same rate as the empty one, you need to push harder.

apply.question: When you jump off a small boat onto a jetty, the boat moves away from the jetty. Use Newton's third law to explain why this happens.
apply.sampleAnswer: When you jump, you push backward against the boat with your feet. According to Newton's third law, the boat pushes back on you with an equal and opposite force, which sends you forward toward the jetty. But your backward push on the boat also moves the boat in the opposite direction - away from the jetty.

analyse.question: A cyclist is travelling at a constant speed on a flat road. What can you say about the forces acting on the cyclist?
analyse.sampleAnswer: If the cyclist is travelling at a constant speed, the forces must be balanced. The forward force from pedalling equals the backward forces from air resistance and friction. The upward force from the road on the tyres equals the downward force of gravity (the cyclist's weight). When all forces are balanced like this, there is no acceleration, so speed stays the same.

unistructural.question: What unit is used to measure force?

multistructural.question: List Newton's three laws of motion.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Newton's three laws are: 1) An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force (law of inertia). 2) Force equals mass times acceleration (F = ma). 3) For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

relational.question: Explain how all three of Newton's laws apply when a footballer kicks a ball.
relational.sampleAnswer: Before the kick, the ball is at rest and stays at rest (first law). When the foot contacts the ball, it applies a force that accelerates the ball - the harder the kick and the lighter the ball, the faster it accelerates (second law, F = ma). At the same time, the ball exerts an equal and opposite force back on the foot - that's why kicking a ball hard can hurt (third law). After the kick, the ball would keep moving in a straight line forever (first law), but air resistance and gravity act on it, slowing it down and curving its path back to Earth.

studentReflection: Think about riding in a car - where do you notice the effects of inertia?
What everyday activities would be impossible without friction?
How might understanding forces help you improve at a sport you play?

B.levelDescription: Developing complexity and academic vocabulary for students approaching year level expectations
whatYouWillLearn: How to describe and calculate speed, velocity, and acceleration
How to apply Newton's three laws to predict motion
The relationship between net force, mass, and acceleration
How momentum is related to mass and velocity
Applications of force and motion concepts in technology and sport

sections.title: Describing Motion Precisely
sections.content: Scientists describe motion using specific terms. Displacement is the change in position in a particular direction - not the total distance travelled. If you walk 5 km north then 5 km south, your total distance is 10 km but your displacement is zero. Speed is the distance travelled divided by time (v = d/t). Average speed considers the whole journey; instantaneous speed is the speed at any particular moment. Velocity includes direction as well as speed - it's displacement divided by time. A velocity of 50 km/h north is different from 50 km/h south. These distinctions are important for precise scientific descriptions of motion.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing the difference between distance and displacement using a walking path

sections.title: Understanding Acceleration
sections.content: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. When something speeds up, slows down, or changes direction, it's accelerating. Acceleration is measured in metres per second per second (m/s²). If a car's velocity increases by 10 m/s every second, its acceleration is 10 m/s². Positive acceleration means speeding up; negative acceleration (deceleration) means slowing down. Acceleration happens when an unbalanced force acts on an object. The direction of acceleration is the same as the direction of the net force. In circular motion, the velocity direction constantly changes, so there's acceleration even if speed stays constant.
sections.visualDescription: Graph showing velocity vs time with acceleration represented by the slope

sections.title: Newton's First Law: The Law of Inertia
sections.content: Newton's first law states that an object will remain at rest or continue moving at constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. Inertia is the property of matter that resists changes to motion. Mass is a measure of inertia - more mass means more inertia. This law explains many observations: objects stay still until pushed; a hockey puck slides across ice until friction stops it; objects in space continue moving indefinitely without engines. The first law also means that constant velocity requires balanced forces - a car cruising at steady speed has driving force balanced by drag and friction.
sections.visualDescription: Illustrations showing objects maintaining their motion states until forces act on them

sections.title: Newton's Second Law: Force and Acceleration
sections.content: Newton's second law quantifies the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration: F = ma, or a = F/m. The net force on an object equals its mass times its acceleration. From this, we see that for a given force, less massive objects accelerate more, and for a given mass, more force means more acceleration. Weight is a force - it's the mass times the acceleration due to gravity (g ≈ 10 m/s² on Earth). So weight W = mg. An 80 kg person weighs 800 N on Earth but only about 130 N on the Moon (where g ≈ 1.6 m/s²). The second law allows us to calculate unknown forces or predict motion when forces are known.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing F = ma relationship with examples at different masses and forces

sections.title: Newton's Third Law: Action and Reaction
sections.content: Newton's third law states that for every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force. These force pairs act on different objects. When you push a wall, the wall pushes back on you with equal force. When Earth pulls you down with gravity, you pull Earth up with equal force (though Earth doesn't noticeably move because of its enormous mass). In propulsion systems, this principle is essential - rockets expel exhaust gases backward, and the gases push the rocket forward. Understanding that action-reaction pairs act on different objects is key - they never cancel each other out because they're on different things.
sections.visualDescription: Force diagrams showing action-reaction pairs on different objects

sections.title: Net Force and Equilibrium
sections.content: When multiple forces act on an object, we find the net force by adding them as vectors - considering both size and direction. Forces in the same direction add; forces in opposite directions subtract. If the net force is zero, forces are balanced and the object is in equilibrium - either at rest or moving at constant velocity. When a book sits on a table, gravity pulls it down but the table pushes up with equal force, so the net force is zero. When forces are unbalanced, the object accelerates in the direction of the net force. Force diagrams (free body diagrams) help visualise all forces acting on an object.
sections.visualDescription: Free body diagrams showing balanced and unbalanced forces with arrows

sections.title: Momentum: Mass in Motion
sections.content: Momentum is a measure of how hard it is to stop a moving object. It depends on both mass and velocity: p = mv (where p is momentum, m is mass, and v is velocity). A heavy truck moving slowly can have the same momentum as a fast-moving car. Momentum is conserved - in any collision, the total momentum before equals the total momentum after. This conservation law helps explain what happens in collisions. To change an object's momentum, you need to apply a force for some time - this is called impulse. The longer the time, the less force needed for the same momentum change, which is why you bend your knees when landing from a jump.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison of momentum for objects with different masses and velocities

sections.title: Applications in Sport and Technology
sections.content: Newton's laws explain phenomena across sports and technology. In AFL, a marking player experiences a large impulse from catching a ball - spreading this over more time (by moving hands backward) reduces the force on their hands. In swimming, propulsion comes from pushing water backward (action), causing the water to push the swimmer forward (reaction). Electric cars accelerate faster than petrol cars because electric motors provide instant torque (rotational force). Spacecraft use Newton's laws for navigation - they fire thrusters briefly then coast through space (first law), adjusting trajectory with calculated burns (second law).
sections.visualDescription: Examples from sport and technology showing Newton's laws in action

caseStudy.title: Space Missions and Newton's Laws
caseStudy.location: Australian Space Agency and NASA collaborations
caseStudy.content: Australia's space program, coordinated through the Australian Space Agency, relies heavily on Newton's laws. The Deep Space Network facility at Canberra is one of only three sites worldwide that can track spacecraft throughout the solar system. When planning missions, engineers use Newton's laws to calculate every aspect of motion. A spacecraft launch requires overcoming Earth's gravity (Newton's second law) - rockets must produce enough upward force to exceed the spacecraft's weight. As fuel burns and the rocket becomes lighter, the same thrust produces greater acceleration. The action of expelling hot gases creates the reaction force that propels the rocket (third law). Once in space, spacecraft obey the first law perfectly - without air resistance, they continue at constant velocity unless thrusters fire. Planning a journey to Mars requires calculating exactly how long to fire thrusters and in which direction. The spacecraft coasts most of the way, using planetary gravity to adjust course. Australia's satellite tracking capabilities ensure mission controllers know exactly where spacecraft are, allowing precise course corrections. These applications of 17th-century physics enable 21st-century space exploration.
questions: How does the third law explain rocket propulsion?
Why does a rocket accelerate faster as it burns fuel?
Why can spacecraft travel between planets without running their engines continuously?

remember.question: State the equation for Newton's second law and define each variable.
remember.sampleAnswer: Newton's second law is F = ma, where F is net force measured in newtons (N), m is mass measured in kilograms (kg), and a is acceleration measured in metres per second squared (m/s²).

understand.question: Explain why a skydiver eventually reaches a constant velocity (terminal velocity) during freefall.
understand.sampleAnswer: Initially, gravity accelerates the skydiver downward. As they speed up, air resistance increases because it depends on velocity. Eventually, air resistance grows large enough to equal the skydiver's weight. At this point, the forces are balanced, net force is zero, and according to Newton's first law, the skydiver continues at constant velocity - this is terminal velocity. They're still falling, but not accelerating.

apply.question: A 1500 kg car accelerates from rest to 20 m/s in 10 seconds. Calculate the net force acting on the car.
apply.sampleAnswer: First, calculate acceleration: a = change in velocity / time = (20 - 0) / 10 = 2 m/s². Then apply Newton's second law: F = ma = 1500 × 2 = 3000 N. The net force on the car is 3000 N.

analyse.question: Compare the momentum of a 2 kg cricket ball travelling at 40 m/s with a 0.058 kg tennis ball travelling at 70 m/s. Which would be harder to stop and why?
analyse.sampleAnswer: Cricket ball momentum: p = mv = 2 × 40 = 80 kg·m/s. Tennis ball momentum: p = mv = 0.058 × 70 = 4.06 kg·m/s. The cricket ball has almost 20 times more momentum. It would be much harder to stop because stopping an object requires applying a force for enough time to reduce its momentum to zero (impulse = change in momentum). More momentum means more impulse needed, so either more force or more time to stop it.

evaluate.question: A student argues that since action and reaction are equal, the forces should cancel out and nothing should ever move. Evaluate this argument and identify the error.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: The error is that action and reaction forces act on different objects, not the same object. Forces only cancel when they act on the same object. When you push a wall, you exert a force on the wall, and the wall exerts an equal force on you - but these forces are on different objects. The wall might accelerate (move slightly or deform) if your push exceeds other forces on it. You might accelerate backward if the wall's push on you exceeds friction at your feet. For motion to occur, we look at the net force on each object separately, not the sum of forces across different objects.

unistructural.question: What is the formula for momentum?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: Momentum equals mass times velocity: p = mv.

multistructural.question: List three factors that affect the acceleration of an object.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: Three factors affecting acceleration are: 1) The magnitude of the net force - greater force causes greater acceleration; 2) The direction of the net force - acceleration is in the same direction as net force; 3) The mass of the object - greater mass means less acceleration for the same force.

relational.question: Explain how the concepts of force, mass, acceleration, and momentum are interconnected.
relational.sampleAnswer: These concepts form an interconnected system. Mass is the amount of matter in an object and determines its inertia. Force is required to change an object's motion, and the relationship is quantified by F = ma - force equals mass times acceleration. So for a given force, more mass means less acceleration. Momentum (p = mv) combines mass and velocity, representing how hard an object is to stop. To change momentum, you apply a force over time (impulse = FΔt = Δp). This connects back to acceleration because changing velocity (which affects momentum) requires acceleration, which requires force. All these relationships derive from Newton's second law and describe different aspects of the same physical reality.

extendedAbstract.question: How might Newton's laws, developed to describe motion on Earth, have limitations when applied to very high speeds or very small scales?
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Newton's laws work extremely well for everyday situations but have limitations at extremes. At very high speeds (approaching the speed of light), Einstein's special relativity becomes necessary. Relativistic effects mean that mass increases with velocity, time dilates, and momentum is more complex than p = mv. Newton's laws give wrong predictions for particle accelerators and GPS satellites. At very small scales (atoms and subatomic particles), quantum mechanics takes over. Particles don't have definite positions and velocities simultaneously (Heisenberg uncertainty), and motion is described by probability waves rather than definite trajectories. Newton's laws are actually an approximation that works when objects are large and slow compared to atoms and light. This doesn't mean Newton was wrong - his laws remain perfectly useful for engineering, sports science, and space missions. Science often works by establishing valid domains for theories rather than replacing them entirely.

studentReflection: How does understanding Newton's laws change how you observe motion in everyday life?
Why do you think it took until Newton for these laws to be clearly stated, given that humans had observed motion for millennia?
What aspects of force and motion are still confusing to you, and how might you investigate them?
